newsitem.title: GERMANY: Health workers march against cuts in Bonn.
newsitem.headline: Health workers march against cuts in Bonn.

text.p: Around 10,000 banner-waving health workers marched on Bonn's health ministry on Tuesday to protest against cuts in Germany's insurance system which they said would cost up to 100,000 jobs.

Physiotherapists, masseurs and home nurses were objecting to a government bill which would leave it to health insurers to decide if they would pay for a range of "optional" treatments, mostly involving home care and rehabilitation.

The bill, the so-called third stage health reform, also provides for patients to pay a higher share of their own health costs in a bid to stem abuse and cut the spiralling costs of the German system, one of the world's most comprehensive.

"The level of health care in Germany can only be maintained by higher patient contributions to medicines and treatments, at a level which is compatible with social welfare," Health Minister Horst Seehofer told a conference in Koenigswinter near Bonn.
He also said claims for treatments and therapies were rising at a rate that bore no relation to medical needs.

"We can no longer afford to have the health system pay for everything from help with marital crises to school problems," he said. "It's time patients stopped expecting so much of the health system and started taking more responsibility for themselves."

Demonstrators in Bonn carried banners reading "Enough is enough" and "Seehofer -- executioner of the disabled, henchman of the drug industry". One carried a model of a skeleton bearing the slogan "Health reform -- fourth stage".
The protesters were planning to hand in a petition of 1.2 million signatures opposing the health reform at Seehofer's ministry.

They included not only health professionals but also representatives of self-help groups for rheumatism and multiple sclerosis who fear that essential home care for sufferers will no longer be paid for.

Welfare groups including the German Red Cross and union- and church-based charities issued a statement calling on the government to step in to prevent the elderly and the chronically ill losing their right to preventative care and rehabilitation.

"The state must not simply cast off its responsibility for the quality and extent of health care provisions," the groups said. "The long-term consequences for society as a whole will be higher than the short-term savings of the health insurers."
